note.p: Julius Junkermann was a Republican public figure and private secretary to a governor in Reconstruction Mississippi.

Born on November 14, 1841, in Dusseldorf, Germany, Junkermann moved to the United States in 1860, settling in New Orleans, Louisiana. When the Civil War broke out the following year, he was forced into Confederate service. He reportedly deserted the Confederate army at the Battle of Corinth, Mississippi, and fled to Union lines, where he volunteered for service. He enlisted in the Forty-third Illinois Infantry Regiment and served in the Union army for the rest of the war.

Junkermann resided in Mississippi after the war and was active in Republican Party politics. He married Clara Eggleston, the daughter of Brevet (honorary) Brigadier General Beroth B. Eggleston, a Union officer originally who helped establish the Republican Party in Mississippi during Reconstruction and unsuccessfully ran for governor of the state in the late 1860s. Junkermann and his wife had one daughter.

Junkermann served as Superintendent of Public Education in Washington County, Mississippi, in the early 1870s before becoming Governor Ridgley Powers’s private secretary in 1872. He was commissioned as Quartermaster General, at the rank of brigadier general, in the Mississippi State Militia in January 1872 and served a wide variety of public offices over the next several years, including circuit court clerk in Washington County and U.S. deputy tax collector in Jackson, Mississippi. Junkermann was also nominated for Mississippi state legislature in 1875, but does not appear to have won.

Junkermann, his wife, and much of his wife’s family, moved to Kansas around 1879, after Reconstruction had ended in the south. He edited a German-language newspaper in Kansas and served as justice of the peace for several years. In the early 1880s, Junkermann experienced unspecified health problems. He traveled to Colorado for treatment in 1883, but his condition worsened and he returned home only a few days later and died on June 1, 1883, in Wichita, Kansas. He is buried in Highland Cemetery in Wichita, Kansas.

(FindaGrave; New Orleans Republican, New Orleans, LA, December 8, 1870; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, January 11, 1872; Daily Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, October 7, 1875; (Register of Officers and Agents, Divil, Military, and Naval, in the Service of the United States on the Thirtieth of September 1877,, 77; Journal of the Senate of the State of Mississippi, 1873, 548; Beroth B. Eggleston, Sedgwick County KSGenWeb; The Wichita Weekly Beacon, Wichita, KS, June 6, 1883)

note.p: William Matthew Strickland was a Confederate soldier and an attorney from Mississippi.

Born in Wake County, North Carolina, on January 1, 1823, Strickland moved to Mississippi as a boy with his family in 1837. Due to health issues, he temporarily left school as a teenager and worked in a mercantile business, owned by his brothers, in Chulahoma, Mississippi. In 1841, he was made supervisor of his father’s plantation. Eventually, he returned to professional studies and pursued a career in law. After apprenticing under two prominent jurists, Strickland began practicing law in the 1850s. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, he volunteered for Confederate service. He joined the Ninth Mississippi Infantry Regiment, and later served as a staff officer under various Confederate generals, including Braxton Bragg and John C. Pemberton. Strickland held the rank of major when the war ended in 1865.

After the war, Strickland returned to his law practice. He was involved in local politics, but largely in a support role rather than a candidate for public office. He did campaign to serve as a presidential elector in 1888. Strickland passed away on March 4, 1908. He was married twice, first to Martha Thompson, who died in 1863. He then married Eliza Jane Leake in 1867. He had at least eight children. Strickland is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(The Grenada Sentinel, Grenada, MS, October 20, 1888; FindaGrave)

James Thornton Fant was an attorney and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born in Alabama on November 8, 1838, Fant graduated from the University of Mississippi in the late 1850s and became a practicing attorney in Holly Springs, Mississippi. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Fant volunteered for Confederate service and served in the Ninth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He was promoted to lieutenant in 1862 and was wounded during the Battle of Munfordville, Kentucky, in September 1862.

After the war he was appointed a district attorney and served in that role for several years in the 1870s. Fant also ran a law firm with his brother, Arthur Fant, and established a good reputation for his legal skills. In 1890, he was appointed circuit judge, to fill the vacancy left by the death of William Rogers. He served for two years and then resigned in 1892. He passed away on August 21, 1895. Fant was married to Clara M. Clayton and had at least one child, who died in infancy. Fant is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; Dunbar Rowland, The Official and Statistical Register of the State of Mississippi, 1908, 593; Alfred E. Fant, Fant genealogy, Entry 920; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, March 20, 1878; The Semi-Weekly Leader, Brookhaven, MS, August 14, 1890; The State Ledger, Jackson, MS, September 20, 1892)

note.p: Ridgley C. Powers served as governor of Mississippi from 1871 to 1874.

Born in Mecca, Ohio, on December 24, 1836, Powers was raised and educated in the north. In 1862, after receiving a degree from the University of Michigan, and conducting graduate work at Union College in New York, Powers enlisted in the Union Army for service during the Civil War. He was promoted to second lieutenant and then captain in the 125th Ohio Infantry Regiment and saw action in Tennessee and Georgia. By the time the Civil War ended in 1865, Powers had achieved the rank of colonel.

Upon separating from the military, Powers settled in Mississippi. He purchased land and began a cotton plantation. He soon became a public figure, serving as sheriff in Noxubee County. By 1868, Powers had gained status in Mississippi’s Republican Party, and was elected lieutenant governor in 1869. Although he was a “carpet bagger” (northerner who settled in the south during Reconstruction), Powers was generally respected by white Mississippians. This was in contrast to Governor James Alcorn, a northern by birth, but who was considered a “scalawag” since he had lived in Mississippi since the 1840s and had served in the Confederacy before joining the Republican Party. When Alcorn resigned the governor’s office in 1871 to take a seat in the U.S. Senate, Powers assumed the state’s executive office. He became active in promoting Mississippi’s economic development and independence, advocating crop variety and lesser dependence upon imported goods. Despite his efforts to maintain a stable political and economic environment in Mississippi, a rift grew among Republicans that led to competing party nominations for governor in 1873. Alcorn was nominated by the more conservative wing of Republicans against Adelbert Ames, former Union general and military governor, who was backed by the radicals. Ames won the election and took the governor’s seat in 1874.

In 1875, shortly after leaving office, Powers married Louisa Born. The couple had one child who died in infancy. They moved to Arizona, but Louisa suffered from a mysterious medical condition and began traveling across the United States and Europe for treatment. She passed away in New York in 1882 after undergoing surgery. Powers later remarried (to Mary Wilson) and moved to California. He spent the rest of his life as a rancher and businessman at Los Angeles. He died on November 11, 1912, and is buried in Angelus Rosedale Cemetery in Los Angeles, California.
(Wikipedia; Mississippi Encyclopedia; FindaGrave)

Located in Shelby County, Memphis was founded in 1819 and serves as the county seat. (Britannica; Wikipedia)

Currently an independent city, Saint Louis was founded on February 14, 1764 in what was then French Territory. On April 29, 1803, it became part of United States territory as part of the Louisiana Purchase, and became part of the St. Louis District on September 30, 1804. It served as the capital of Louisiana Territory from 1805 until 1812, and the capital of Missouri Territory from 1812 until 1821. On December 6, 1812, St. Louis District became St. Louis County. Saint Louis was incorporated in 1822 and became an independent city on October 21, 1876. (Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located in Jackson County, Missouri, Kansas City was founded in the 1830s, incorporated as a town on June 1, 1850, and incorporated as a city on March 28, 1853. During the Civil War, Kansas City was the location of numerous intense battles, including the First and Second Battles of Independence, and the Battle of Westport in 1864. Kansas City remained under Union control, even though it was surrounded by significant numbers of Confederate supporters in rural areas. Kansas City was the Union's District of the Border headquarters throughout the war. Following the Civil War, Kansas City's population boomed and its city limits were extended. Presently, Kansas City is the largest city in Missouri. (Wikipedia; "Kansas City, Missouri, The Missouri Kansas Conflict, 1854–1865," Civil War on the Western Border)

Located in Pulaski County, Little Rock was founded in 1820 and became the state capital of Arkansas. It was incorporated as a town in 1831 and as a city in 1835. Little Rock serves as the county seat and continues to serve as the state capital of Arkansas. (Encyclopedia of Arkansas; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)Located in Pulaski County, Arkansas, Little Rock was settled in 1812, incorporated on November 7, 1831, and serves as both the county seat and state capitol. (Encyclopedia of Arkansas; Wikipedia)

Located in Denver County, Colorado, Denver was settled in the 1850s, incorporated on November 7, 1861, and serves as the county seat and state capital. Denver emerged during the Pike's Peak Gold Rush, initially as several competing settlements. Denver's strategic location and aggressive promotion led to its establishment as the territorial capital of Colorado. Post-Civil War, Denver's connection to the transcontinental railroad fueled rapid growth, transforming it into a major urban center. However, this growth was accompanied by social tensions, including the rise of organized crime and the Ku Klux Klan. (Wikipedia; Colorado Encyclopedia)Located in northeast Colorado, Denver is a consolidated city-county that was founded on November 22, 1858 under the name Denver City. It was incorporated on November 7, 1861, when it became the county seat of Arapahoe County. Denver City was renamed Denver when it became the state capital in 1881, and remains so today. It was consolidated on December 1, 1902. (Wikipedia; Britannica; Colorado Encyclopedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Alcorn County, Corinth was founded in 1853 under the name Cross City in what was then Tishomingo County. When Alcorn County was created on April 15, 1870, Corinth became its county seat. (Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Marshall County, Holly Springs was founded in 1836 in what was then Monroe County. When Marshall County was created on March 1, 1836, Holly Springs became its county seat. (Rowland, Mississippi, 874; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: A paramilitary organization is a group of armed individuals that act in a pseudo-military fashion, but is not an official military unit. Paramilitary groups are often associated with illegal or revolutionary actions, and frequently use guerilla warfare or even terrorism to achieve their objectives. The term paramilitary arose in the twentieth century, however examples of paramilitary-style groups during the Civil War include Missouri Bushwhackers and Kansas Jayhawkers, who engaged in guerilla warfare, and sometimes terrorist or criminal actions, ostensibly for their respective side. Some of these units were eventually accepted into formal military service within the Union and Confederate armies, while others operated with only tacit endorsement by the warring governments.

Paramilitary groups are more commonly associated to the Reconstruction era, when bands of armed citizens in the south organized to resist state and federal authorities who supported Republican policies. The most well-known examples include the Ku Klux Klan, the White League, and the Red Shirts. The Klan started as a fraternal order in 1865 among former Confederate soldiers in Tennessee but rapidly became a terrorist group, whose members often wore hoods to hide their identities. It became the most famous group dedicated to intimidating Republicans and African Americans in the south to maintain white supremacy. The White League was formed in the early 1870s in Louisiana, but spread openly across the south for the purpose of using violence to intimidate Republican officials and Black southerners who challenged white supremacy. The White League grew so strong as a paramilitary group that it mustered 5,000 members to outnumber and defeat the New Orleans police force and a state militia unit in a battle in New Orleans in 1873. The Red Shirts emerged around 1875 in Mississippi to oppose Republican Reconstruction and, likewise, enforce white supremacy over Black southerners, often through demonstrations at voting centers. These groups, and others in the south during the latter part of the nineteenth century, were organized, armed, and driven by political and social objectives, but were not formal military units or officially part of their state and local governments (even when they were supported by sympathetic officials).

White supremacist paramilitary groups reversed civil rights progress during the last years of Reconstruction and afterwards, and maintained a steady presence for many years, using intimidation and terrorism, to oppose efforts by white and Black southerners seeking racial equality. (Wikipedia)
While the Cambridge Dictionary defines death as “the end of life,” CWRGM employs this subject tag to refer to human deaths only, both actual and hypothetical. (Cambridge Dictionary)

The nation experienced mass loss of life (approximately 2% of the population) during the American Civil War, which changed the way Americans viewed death and resulted in its reconceptualization in highly bureaucratized ways. Often wartime dead were buried without their names and sometimes in poorly-dug graves, which created a powerful, profound social and cultural dislocation for their surviving loved ones. During the 19th century, Americans understood dying as a social and religious experience, and desired a "good death," which they defined as at home surrounded by family, but these ideals were unattainable in war. Consequently, Americans learned to cope with death and memorialize it in new ways. Unionists encouraged the federal government and ex-Confederates pushed their respective state governments to create and fund national cemeteries, rebury deceases soldiers and veterans, and establish veterans' and widows' pensions. These new responses to death were more bureaucratized, nationalistic, and secularized. Wartime and post-war death was also highly impacted by race, as white supremacists desecrated the graves of Union buried in the South, especially the bodies of African Americans who served in U.S. Colored Troops and the white officers that led them, revealing post-war sectionalism and strains on reconciliation. (Drew Gilpin Faust, This Republic of Suffering)

div.p:
WM. M. STRICKLAND. [gap] JAS. T. FANT.
Office of Strickland & Fant,
Attorneys at Law,
Holly Springs, Miss., Jany 15th 1873

Hon R. C. Powers
Govr of Miss.
Dear Sir:

The enclosed letter of Sheriff Gillenwaters explains itself; The Killing, as the evidence proves was a very unprovoked affair, and if consistently with the duties of your Excellency and the laws of the land, a reward can be offered, it may be the means of bringing the murderer to Justice,
The letter is respectfully referred to your excellency
Very Respectfully

Jas T. Fant
District Attorney
10th Dist.

[fold] OFFICE,
ALCORN COUNTY,
[fold]WATERS, Sheriff.
Corinth, Miss., Jany 10th 1873

Jas T. Fant
Dist Atty
Holly Springs
Dr Sir

On the night of the 31st Dec 1872, a Party of Masqued men went to the Jail at this place and rescued a man by the name of Eve. Barefoot, who had on the 24th day of Dec murdered a man in our town by the name of Peter Cade I offered a reward of one hundred Dollars for his arrest, and sent an ditachment of men, who traversed the county for two days without any success. I then notified the Secretary of the Govenor and asked of him a reward for the said Barefoot seeing that no reward has been offered by the Govenor, I would respe-ctfully ask that your influence be used with him for a reward. I have not as yet been able to hear a word of Barefoot, but still have

hope of his capture. I notified the Chief of Police at Memphis, St Louis Kansas City, Little Rock Ark and Denver City Omehaw, believing that he would go west, gave them all a full description of Barefoot—and promised a reward of One hundred Dollars from myself and a handsome reward from the Govenor therefore hope you will use your influ-ence for the reward to be offered

Jno. E. Gillenwaters
Shff &c

Description
Eve Barefoot 19 years old 5 ft 8 inces high Heavy built Weight about 145# quick spoken & has rather a bold appearance dark hair and Eyes, wears his hair shingled close
